For accessing compounds 11 and 12, depicted in Scheme 1, the key intermediate is per- O-benzylated 1-DNJ 6, which was accessed in a 5-step linear pathway (36% overall yield), following the procedure reported in the literature
42 , starting from commercially-available methyl α- d-glucopyranoside 1 ( Scheme 1). Such procedure involves fully O-protection, acidic hydrolysis of the glycoside moiety, reduction of the masked aldehyde of 3, Swern oxidation
43 , and fast reductive amination of transient unstable dicarbonyl compound 5; the last step consists of a double reductive amination (DRA), a cascade reaction that provides a straightforward methodology for accessing polyhydroxylated piperidines
44 . Base-promoted N-alkylation with bromoderivatives 7 and 8, and deprotection by hydrogenolysis, furnished compounds 11 and 12, respectively, with the substitution pattern depicted in Scheme 1. We hypothesised that the presence of one or two methoxy groups could resemble the dimethoxy arene-based fragment of the indanone moiety in donepezil, and thus, might enable interaction with the PAS region of cholinesterases. Moreover, the use of a o-dihydroxyphenyl ring (catechol moiety) could afford relevant antioxidant properties
45 , as well as the capacity for chelating metal ions (Zn, Cu, Fe are present at toxic levels in the brain of Alzheimer’s patients)
46 .
